prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: The world-famous 'great detective', above whose lodgings Miss Susato and I rent our own office and rooms.
Character 2
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 3
Name: Pop Windibank
Description: The proprietor of a pawnbrokery on Baker Street that is regularly patronised by Mr Sholmes. He has a very great sense of responsibility to his clients.
Character 4
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A young pickpocket who we first met during a trial two months ago. She and Iris have become firm friends since.
Character 5
Name: Eggert Benedict → Ashley Graydon
Description: A young English gentleman with an aloof and high-handed manner. He appeared at Windibank's pawnbrokery accusing Gina of stealing his redemption ticket.
Character 6
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 7
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: The infamous London-based prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Further details about the man are not forthcoming.
Character 9
Name: Nash Skulkin
Description: A witness to the event who broke into Windibank's on the night of the murder with his brother and accomplice Ringo. He claims to be a 'profeshnal baddie' by trade.
Character 10
Name: Ringo Skulkin
Description: A witness to the event who broke into Windibank's on the night of the murder with his brother and accomplice Nash. He claims to be a 'profeshnal baddie' by trade.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Music Box Disk
Description: A metal disk used to play music in a mechanical music box. The piece of music, which remains unidentified, is stored on the disk by means of small protrusions. A metal disk used to play music in a mechanical music box. On the reverse side is a note that reads, 'For McGilded'.
Evidence 2
Name: White Cat Photograph → Pawnbroker's Ticket (Box)
Description: A photograph depicting a sweet little white cat, obtained from Gina while interviewing her in her prison cell. A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank, in the form of some hand-written notes on the back of a photograph.
Evidence 3
Name: Gina's Representation Papers
Description: The paperwork signed by Gina to put me in charge of her defence. Showing this to Scotland Yard detectives gains us access to the crime scene.
Evidence 4
Name: White Cat Photograph #2 → Pawnbroker's Ticket (Coat)
Description: A photograph depicting a sweet little white cat. I feel as though I have another print just like this one... A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank. There's what looks like a bloody fingermark on it. A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank. The blood on it has been identified as Mr Mason's.
Evidence 5
Name: Blood Samples Portfolio
Description: A sample of blood analysed with a special chemical indicator developed by Mr Sholmes. Different people's blood turns different colours.
Evidence 6
Name: Iris's Story Manuscript
Description: A long, unpublished story that Mr Sholmes deposited at the pawnbrokery of the victim, Mr Windibank. It's entitled 'The Hound of the Baskervilles'.
Evidence 7
Name: McGilded Case Notes
Description: Notes collated by Miss Susato about the McGilded case that we worked on two months ago.
Evidence 8
Name: Today's Paper
Description: This morning's paper, purchased by Iris. Gina's case features prominently. This morning's paper, which contains an article about government secrets being leaked to foreign agencies.
Evidence 9
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: A report prepared by the Scotland Yard coroner that confirms instant death due to a single bullet wound from the back. There are no other signs of trauma.
Evidence 10
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photograph of the victim found murdered in the storeroom. It shows the single bullet wound in the man's back.
Evidence 11
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of Windibank's pawnbrokery, the scene of the crime. It shows the relative positions of the main shop and the rear storeroom.
Evidence 12
Name: Windibank's Gun
Description: A gun belonging to the victim, Mr Windibank, that Gina was holding when she was found unconscious. There are signs of a single discharge.
Evidence 13
Name: Skulkin Brothers' Gun
Description: A firearm found in the possession of the Skulkin brothers upon their arrest. There are signs that a single round was fired.
Evidence 14
Name: Photograph of Gina
Description: A photograph taken automatically by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene a short time before the murder took place.
Evidence 15
Name: Post-Shooting Photograph
Description: A photograph taken automatically by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene after the murder had taken place.
Evidence 16
Name: Stereoscope
Description: A fold-up device that allows anybody to enjoy seeing things in three dimensions simply by looking through the eyepieces.
Evidence 17
Name: Sholmes's Pouch
Description: The pouch Mr Sholmes was wearing around his waist at the time of the shooting. One of the glass phials is smashed and there are scorch marks around it.
Evidence 18
Name: The Third Bullet
Description: A projectile we discovered lodged in Mr Sholmes's pouch. It caused one of the phials to explode, injuring Mr Sholmes.
Evidence 19
Name: Small Music Box
Description: This strange music box only appears to be able to play a single tone. It was deposited at Windibank's two days before the black overcoat.
Evidence 20
Name: Cat-Flapomat
Description: A compact machine for the rapid creation of small flaps in larger doors, to allow cats to come and go freely.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: Alright, we did knock a few things over. But we weren't riflin' fer nuffin'!
Person: Nash
Testimony 1
Testimony: It woz when we 'eard the gunshot, see. Made us both jump, an' all that stuff went flyin'.
Person: Ringo
Testimony 2
Testimony: Just before the gunshot, we 'eard a voice yellin' out, 'Gimme that gun!'
Person: Ringo
Testimony 3
Testimony: The bloke wot owned the place was 'oldin' a gun, so 'e should 'ave just fired instead of yellin' at the girl!
Person: Nash
Testimony 4
Testimony: Lummy, it didn't 'alf gimme a fright! We woz thinkin' the shooter'd come out the door and get us next.
Person: Nash
Testimony 5
Testimony: We stuck everyfin' back where we found it and scarpered...straight into 'im in the black.
Person: Ringo
Testimony 6
Testimony: We couldn't 'ave shot the pawnbroker, see! We never even 'ad a chance, did we?
Person: Nash

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. I'm a bit new to this, so I'll take it step by step.

First, I'll look at the evidence provided. There are 20 pieces of evidence listed, but I'll focus on the ones that seem relevant. Evidence 14 is a photograph of Gina taken by the Red-Handed Recorder, which shows the scene before the murder. Evidence 15 is another photograph taken after the shooting. These two seem important because they show the timeline of events.

Looking at the testimonies, the Skulkin brothers, Nash and Ringo, are the main witnesses. Nash says they didn't steal anything and that they were scared when they heard the gunshot. Ringo mentions hearing a voice yelling, "Gimme that gun!" just before the shot. They both claim they didn't shoot the pawnbroker and fled immediately after.

Now, I need to find a contradiction. If the photographs (Evidence 14 and 15) show that the Skulkin brothers were present at the scene before and after the shooting, their testimony claiming they didn't shoot and were just there by chance might be false. The photographs could show their involvement, contradicting their alibi.

So, the key contradiction is between the evidence showing their presence and their testimony denying any involvement in the shooting.
</think>

Testimony 0
Testimony: Naturally, I have occasion to make use of pawnbroking services from time to time.
Person: Graydon
Testimony 1
Testimony: But are you seriously suggesting I colluded with these thugs to break into the place on the night of the murder?
Person: Graydon
Testimony 2
Testimony: ...I have no intention of admitting to such an outrageous accusation.
Person: Graydon
Testimony 3
Testimony: Even if certain parties here present claim that my blood was found at the scene.
Person: Graydon
Testimony 4
Testimony: Some scaramouch detective's homebrewed tincture can hardly be taken as serious evidence.

cot:
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let me go through the information step by step.

First, I'll look at the characters involved. There's Eggert Benedict, who's accusing Gina of stealing a redemption ticket. Gina is a young pickpocket who was involved in a trial before. The Skulkin brothers are witnesses who broke into Windibank's pawnbrokery, claiming to be professional criminals. 

Looking at the evidence, there's a pawnbroker's ticket with a bloodstain identified as Mr. Mason's. This suggests that someone was involved in a violent act at the scene. 

Now, the testimonies. Eggert Benedict is denying any involvement in the crime, saying he's never been to the pawnbrokery where the murder happened. However, the pawnbroker's ticket with his blood indicates that he was indeed present at the scene. 

So, the contradiction is between the pawnbroker's ticket (evidence) and Benedict's testimony denying his presence. The evidence shows he was there, while he claims he wasn't.
</think>

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: There's a note on the disk saying, 'For McGilded', but the item belongs to me.
Person: Graydon
Testimony 1
Testimony: The redemption ticket was stolen from me by the accused - that filthy gutterling - on the day in question.
Person: Graydon
Testimony 2
Testimony: I proceeded at once to the shop in order to explain my situation and redeem my article.
Person: Graydon
Testimony 3
Testimony: In the end, of course, the disk was taken by the police.
Person: Graydon
Testimony 4
Testimony: In other words...I had absolutely no reason to break into the shop later that same night.
Person: Graydon

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, let's tackle this problem step by step. I've been given a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies, and I need to find a pair where an evidence contradicts a testimony. 

First, I'll look through the characters to understand who's involved. There are several key players like Susato Mikotoba, Herlock Sholmes, Iris Wilson, Pop Windibank, Gina Lestrade, Eggert Benedict (Ashley Graydon), and others. The case seems to involve a murder at a pawnbrokery, with suspects and various pieces of evidence pointing towards different possibilities.

Next, I'll review the evidences provided. Evidence 1 is a music box disk with a note saying "For McGilded." Evidence 4 is a photograph of a white cat with a pawnbroker's ticket that has blood identified as Mr. Mason's. There's also blood sample analysis (Evidence 5), Iris's manuscript (Evidence 6), and other items like guns and photographs.

Looking at the testimonies, Graydon (Eggert Benedict) claims that the redemption ticket was stolen by Gina and that he had no reason to break into the shop. He also mentions a note on the disk saying "For McGilded."

Now, I need to find a contradiction. Evidence 1 mentions the disk with "For McGilded," while Graydon's testimony (Testimony 0) also refers to this note. However, the contradiction arises because Graydon claims the disk belongs to him, but the evidence suggests it was used in a context related to McGilded, possibly implicating someone else. 

Therefore, the pair that contradicts is Evidence 1 and Testimony 0.
</think>

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, so I've got this problem where I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let's see, the user provided a bunch of characters, evidences, and testimonies. My job is to look through them and find a pair that contradicts each other.

First, I need to understand what each evidence and testimony says. Let's go through them one by one.

Looking at the evidence, there's a lot here. Evidence 1 is a music box disk with a note saying "For McGilded." Evidence 4 is a redemption ticket with a bloody fingerprint. Testimony 0 from Graydon says the music box disk belongs to him and there's no reason he'd break into the shop later. Testimony 1 says the redemption ticket was stolen by Gina.

Hmm, so if the redemption ticket was stolen by Gina, that would mean Graydon didn't steal it. But Graydon's testimony says he had no reason to break in. Wait, but if the ticket was stolen, that might mean someone else, like the Skulkins, broke in. 

So, the contradiction is that Graydon says the disk is his and he had no reason to break in, but the evidence shows the ticket was stolen, implying someone else did it. So, the evidence (like the ticket) contradicts Graydon's testimony that he didn't break in.

Therefore, the answer is {"evidence": 4, "testimony": 0}.
</think>

cot:
Alright, let's tackle this problem step by step. I'm given a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies, and I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other.

First, I'll go through each evidence and testimony to understand what they say.

Looking at the testimonies, Graydon is testifying about the events during the murder. He claims that when Windibank threw Nash over the counter, he felt a sharp pain in his arm. He then pursued Windibank, saw him through the peephole, and watched as the accused, in a black coat, shot Windibank in the back. Graydon also says he saw blood spatter on Gina and then she tossed the gun out, which he picked up and used to escape.

Now, looking at the evidence, specifically evidence 14, it's a photograph taken by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene before the murder. This evidence likely captures the exact moments before the crime, possibly showing who was where and what happened.

If Graydon's testimony is accurate, the photograph from evidence 14 should corroborate his account. However, if the photograph shows something different—like Graydon not being near the entrance or not being the one to pick up the gun after the murder—then there's a contradiction.

Considering the details, if the photograph (evidence 14) doesn't align with Graydon's description of his actions and movements, it would contradict his testimony. For example, if the photo shows someone else near the entrance or the gun in a different position, Graydon's account would be proven false.

Therefore, the contradiction lies between evidence 14 and testimony 1.
